data.body:
Thanks.

I think we should remove `Texture` specific code from `processImage()`.

https://github.com/kickblade/three.js/blob/5e50c2138dc6755bc5df4aa7b1c9bb63bbdcf0af/examples/js/exporters/GLTFExporter.js#L640-L645

If two textures share one image and one texture's `.flipY` is `true` while another one is `false`, 

https://github.com/kickblade/three.js/blob/5e50c2138dc6755bc5df4aa7b1c9bb63bbdcf0af/examples/js/exporters/GLTFExporter.js#L619

similarly, if one texutre's `.format` is `RGBAFormat` while another one is not, one of the textures will be broken.

Yeah, that would be one of the options.

About `.flipY`, does glTF spec or extension has a plan to support `.flipY` property in texture? IIRC, I think I've seen the discussion in glTF issues.

There is no `flipY` in glTF (maybe it was in a previous version?) but the `KHR_texture_transforms` extension will add offset/repeat/rotation. I think duplicating the image if it's used with flipY both true and false is fine, that should be rare. ~~When texture transforms are supported (eventually) we should try to avoid duplicating the image though.~~

Yeah, I think duplication is ok so far, too.

> we should try to avoid duplicating the image though.

by simulating .flipY with offset + repeat of `KHR_texture_transforms` extension, correct?

No, I think two different `flipY` values should always result in a duplicated image unless glTF adds a `flipY` flag. We could also log a warning. Trying to simulate it with negative scale will get messy, especially since three.js texture transforms are currently per-material, not per-texture.

Hm, I've misread?

> When texture transforms are supported 

That meant, "When `flipY` flag is supported in glTF texture spec"?

> That meant, "When flipY flag is supported in glTF texture spec"?

No, I don't think that `flipY` will be supported in the glTF spec. glTF _will_ eventually have texture UV transforms (offset/repeat/rotation), but they are not really the same thing as `texture.flipY`, so I don't think we should try to use one to imitate the other. If one image is used with two different values of `flipY`, we should either duplicate the image or throw an error. It will be too complicated otherwise — what about when texture scale is animated, and then we have to rewrite the animation values to reflect `flipY`? I don't think that's worth it, too much work for a very unlikely case.

I have the same opinion. I don't think it's a good idea to simulate `.flipY` with transforms.

What I wanted to first do is to understand what you mentioned. Probably this is just a English question. (Sorry for my bad English!) 

> When texture transforms are supported (eventually) we should try to avoid duplicating the image though.

I thought you mentioned that "When `KHR_texture_transforms` extension becomes available we Three.js glTF exporter can avoid exporting two images for flipY true and false by using the extension" but it seems I'm wrong?

> I thought you mentioned that "When KHR_texture_transforms extension becomes available we Three.js glTF exporter can avoid exporting two images for flipY true and false by using the extension" but it seems I'm wrong?

Oops sorry, I wrote that poorly... `KHR_texture_transforms` should let us export `texture.offset` and `texture.repeat` but should not have any relationship to `texture.flipY`. We would keep duplicating the image if two `flipY` values are needed, even with `KHR_texture_transforms`.
OK OK, I understand. As I said, I have the same opinion. Thanks for patience!

These are all great points guys. I'll update the empty line, easy. Will try a few ideas out and get back to you soon, bit snowed at the moment. Current thoughts though:

- processImage(map) should be processImage(image, mimeType, flipY)?
Allowing access to map/texture-centric properties after the cache checks will be dangerous now. I think it makes sense to change this so we restrict it. It also makes the function a bit more predictable too (processImage processes images instead of textures). 
- Maybe there's a way to generate a map key from these params, so we can have a more direct lookup (as an alternative to pulling an array of different configs).

I'll have a muck around anyway and get back to you guys when I have something useful :-)

Hi @donmccurdy, just to let you know I've got back on to trying a few things out for this. I think both of your ideas are good, just wouldn't mind trying some ideas out before we plump for one. Maybe give me until the end of the weekend and then you can make a call on the one to put in?

No wonder this feature was marked as a TODO :-)

@takahirox yeh I think that's the neatest solution, nice! I've updated the pull request so you can hopefully the see the final version. I made one minor change to the way the key was constructed to get rid of the 'if' statement. Personally think it's clearer to construct that key on one line with a standard formation but let me know if you disagree and I'll update it no worries at all :-) I've tested this with my particular use-case and it works gloriously! Let me know if there's anything else in there you'd rather change too, it's all good :-)
Thanks for the update!
Sweet, I'll do this over the weekend. Makes sense.
Looks good to me other than that one change!

Just pushed an update to the branch with that change @takahirox. Also added "flipY/" explicitly in the key so now it reads "image/png:flipY/true" or "image/jpg:flipY/false" etc. @donmccurdy can you confirm this commit addresses the change you were referring to, wasn't sure if it was the one takahirox requested or the one I made to the key :-)

Thank you very much for all your help and input guys! This is my first contribution to a public github project, it's been a pleasure. As always, let me know if there's anything you need me to do before merging it in.

> @donmccurdy can you confirm this commit addresses the change you were referring to...

Yep, looks good. Thank you!
Nice work! I request one minor comment correction but others look fine.
Done :-) do you need me to squash any of these commits or will you just merge the whole branch history over?
It's up to @mrdoob but IMO I don't think you need to squash
Sweet, thanks, will see what he says.
@mrdoob this is ready to merge. 👍
Thanks!
